MARKET RECAP

The market opened higher today assisted by progressive China-US trade developments, in particular tech (NFLX, CRM, AMZN, FB, ORCL) and semiconductors (AVGO, AMD, MU). Industrial heavyweights Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT) also traded higher on trade developments. The energy sector was uplifted by the rise in crude oil prices which stayed in the green for most of the session. United Rentals (URI) outperformed following the announcement of a resumed share repurchase programme and strong 2019 outlook. Tencent Music Entertainment (TME) surged on its US IPO today. Following a raise in yields today, financial stocks BlackRock (BLK) and JPMorgan (JPM); in turn, the real estate sector (SPG, AMT, PSA, VTR) underperformed. Verizon (VZ) opened lower on the back of a downgrade at Morgan Stanley, weighing down the telecoms sector. More broadly, the defensive utilities and consumer discretionary sectors underperformed out of the pack as risk appetite improved today. SPX +0.54% at 2651, NDX +0.89% at 6763, DJI +0.64% at 24527.

Positive risk sentiment pressured the complex on Wednesday which remained in negative territory; in early US trade, selling action extended after WSJ reports suggested that China are looking to boost access to oversee countries. The complex pared back some losses after the 10-year auction which was soft overall. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end and belly of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps at settlement. Spreads were mixed but mostly steeper heading into the close. The US treasury sold USD 24bln of 10-year tailing by 0.5bps at a high yield 2.915%. Demand for the auction was below recent averages as indicated by the bid-to-cover which was the lowest since February. Indirects were awarded the smallest share since August, directs took the largest portion since September and dealers were left with a share close to recent averages. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 5+ tick lower at 120-09.

subject: RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 12th December 2018 - PM May survives confidence vote
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.


* SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, treasuries down, dollar down, crude down.

* REAR-VIEW: UK PM May survives confidence vote, China preparing to increase access, US CPI flat, Italian deficit goal now at 2.04%.

* AHEAD: SNB, Norges, ECB and CBRT Interest Rate Decisions & Press Conferences (ex-CBRT), German CPI (Final), US Import and Export Prices, Japanese Tankan Survey, US 30yr Bond Auction.

* BREXIT: UK PM May has survived the no confidence motion against her leadership of the Conservative Party, winning the vote by 200 - 117. The vote represented a comfortable victory, given that 199 voted for her to be leader of the Conservative Party. According to reports earlier in the session, May pledged to Conservative lawmakers that should would not lead the party into the next General Election in 2022, implying that she wants to get the Brexit deal through, and then hand the reins over to someone else. Following the results, sterling dropped from 1.2640 to below 1.2600 with traders seemingly concerned about margins of MPs voting against her leadership.

* TRADE: The WSJ reported that China are preparing to increase access for overseas companies, adding that Beijing is working to replace its “Made in China 2025” plan with one that plays down its bid to dominate manufacturing. White House Chief Economist Kevin Hassett said that China trade talks have made positive progress while US Commerce Secretary Ross stated that European car names, citing BMW, will benefit from China lowering US auto import tariffs; he also noted that the US travel advisory news was just a rumour and that Trump has not made a decision yet on the Huawei CFO. Separately, European Parliament lawmakers have approved the beginning of a free trade deal between the EU and Japan. Elsewhere, the US has rejected the EU trade reform proposal, placing the WTO at risk.

* GEOPOLITICS: A source cited by Interfax announced that the EU will react to Russia's actions in Azov Sea with 6-month sanctions extensions. This followed comments from a German government official who stated there was no consensus within the EU over imposing fresh sanctions on the country.

*  ITALY: Following his meeting with EU Commission President Juncker, Italy’s PM Conte announced that the 2019 deficit goal is now 2.04%/GDP and stressed that the proposals to tweak next year's budget don't betray promises to Italians; he reassured that citizens income will be part of the manoeuvre.

* US CPI was flat in November pushing the yy figure lower to 2.2% from 2.5% mostly reflecting the recent plunge in oil prices. Apparel, transport fares and personal computers were also softer. The core inflation measure rose 0.2% supported by housing, medical care and recreation. Looking ahead, ING analysts expect core measures to climb through the first half of 2019 also noting that PPI is moving higher as “pipeline pressures are building more broadly in an economy which has rapidly been eating into its spare capacity”. They likewise note that the latest inflation data should continue to support the Fed’s hiking trajectory with the next rate hike now almost fully priced at next Thursday’s meeting; looking at the longer-term ING forecasts “three further 25bp rate hikes next year”.

* WTI (F9) SETTLES USD 0.50 LOWER AT USD 51.15/BBL, BRENT (F9) SETTLES USD 0.05 LOWER AT USD 60.15/BBL.  Oil prices held on to their recent gains for most of the session underpinned by risk-on market sentiment as well as today’s DoE crude inventories coinciding with a large crude draw in APIs; distillates also showed a larger than expected draw and gasoline a smaller than anticipated build. Nonetheless, gains were pared back sharply in pre-settlement trade as equities came off their highs, pushing WTI in negative territory. The latest OPEC monthly report saw crude production falling 11k BPD in November to average 32.97mln BPD while also forecasting global oil demand increasing by 1.5mln BPD and 1.29mln BPD in 2018 and 2019, respectively. Production is seen growing by 2.5mln BPD and 2.16bln BPD in 2018 and 2019, respectively; Citi argues that the figures “still reflect the state of the market prior to the OPEC+ production cuts which will trim both the non-OPEC supply numbers and OPEC’s own output from January” and markets are yet to determine whether that will be enough “to keep a floor under prices”. In news flow, the WSJ reported that Saudi and Kuwait are nearing a restart of the joint oil-field pact in Q1 2019 as the US has brokered a deal.

 SPX +0.54% at 2651, NDX +0.89% at 6763, DJI +0.64% at 24527. SECTORS: Energy +0.33%, Materials +0.95%, Industrials +0.54%, Cons Discretionary +1.05%, Cons Staples -0.16%, Healthcare +0.86%, Financials +0.44%, Tech +0.79%, Telecoms +0.82%, Utilities -0.58%.

*STOCK SPECIFICS: The market opened higher today assisted by progressive China-US trade developments, in particular tech (NFLX, CRM, AMZN, FB, ORCL) and semiconductors (AVGO, AMD, MU). Industrial heavyweights Boeing (BA) and Caterpillar (CAT) also traded higher on trade developments. The energy sector was uplifted by the rise in crude oil prices which stayed in the green for most of the session. United Rentals (URI) outperformed following the announcement of a resumed share repurchase programme and strong 2019 outlook. Tencent Music Entertainment (TME) surged on its US IPO today. Following a raise in yields today, financial stocks BlackRock (BLK) and JPMorgan (JPM); in turn, the real estate sector (SPG, AMT, PSA, VTR) underperformed. Verizon (VZ) opened lower on the back of a downgrade at Morgan Stanley, weighing down the telecoms sector. More broadly, the defensive utilities and consumer discretionary sectors underperformed out of the pack as risk appetite improved today.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (Z8) SETTLE  5+ TICK LOWER AT 120-09. Positive risk sentiment pressured the complex on Wednesday which remained in negative territory; in early US trade, selling action extended after WSJ reports suggested that China are looking to boost access to oversee countries. The complex pared back some losses after the 10-year auction which was soft overall. Most of the action was concentrated in the front end and belly of the curve where yields were higher by c.3bps at settlement. Spreads were mixed but mostly steeper heading into the close. The US treasury sold USD 24bln of 10-year tailing by 0.5bps at a high yield 2.915%. Demand for the auction was below recent averages as indicated by the bid-to-cover which was the lowest since February. Indirects were awarded the smallest share since August, directs took the largest portion since September and dealers were left with a share close to recent averages.

* 30-YEAR BONDS PREVIEW: The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of 3-year notes (Tues), USD 24bln of 10-year notes (Wed) and USD 16bln of 30-year bonds (Thu). Societe Generale says the 30-year auction lacks set up: “The sector seems rich on the Treasury spline versus the old 30s, with the outright yield trading below the past two auction stops and rich by almost 30bp compared with the November stop,” adding that “the sector is not particularly cheap on the curve, the 5s30s curve flattening by more than 6bp since last Friday.” SocGen also notes that the November cycle saw demand drop with funds reducing their takedown, which weighed on the performance of the auction; additionally, the proximity to next week’s FOMC meeting (where the central bank is expected to lift rates by 25bps) could act as a negative. However, on the other side of the coin, SocGen sys that any cover demand from the large short positioning in the sector may help support demand.

* EUR: As noted, Eur/Usd has bounced firmly from worst levels near 1.1300 and key support just above the big figure, with a hefty 2.4 bn option expiry also propping prices up along with reports about more convergence between Italy and the EU on 2019 budget lines, and a generally soft Greenback. The headline pair is back over 1.1350 as a result, while the DXY has pulled back further from best levels (97.500) breaking below 97.000 in wake of broadly as expected US CPI data and soft real earnings.

* CAD, AUD, NZD: More divergence for the non-US Dollars as the Loonie derived momentum from firm oil prices and  the latest rise in overall risk sentiment to extend recovery gains around 1.3350, while the Aud appears to be establishing a solid base above 0.7200 as the primary currency proxy for changing US-China trade dynamics (aside from the Yuan of course – Usd/Cnh down from recent 6.9000+ highs and below the overnight Usd/Cny PBoC midpoint fix). Conversely, the Kiwi was unable to keep its head above 0.6850 as the Aud/Nzd cross around 1.0550, despite praise from RBNZ’s Orr for its outstanding behaviour.

* JPY, CHF: The renowned, if not always conforming safe-havens remained relatively rangebound given the ongoing revival in risk appetite on latest reports that China is looking to revise intentions set out in the 2025 plan and relax rules of access for foreign companies, plus growing support for the UK Conservative Party head and speculation that Rome may be getting close to the 2% deficit mark. Usd/Jpy was capped by heavy domestic supply at 113.50 and drifted back towards 113.25, while the Franc pushed just above 0.9900.

* EM: The Rand stood out amidst widespread gains vs the Buck, with more headway made on a chart basis and following SA inflation data that beat consensus – Usd/Zar testing 14.1000 from 14.3500+ at one stage.

* COMING-UP:

* PREVIEW: ECB Monetary Policy Decision Due At 12:45 GMT, 13:45 CET, 07:45 EST, On Thursday 13th December 2018, Press Conference Due At 13:30 GMT, 14:30 CET 08:30 EST. Unanimous expectations look for the ECB to leave its three key rates unchanged. Will the bank continue to view risks to the Eurozone economy as broadly balanced? Focus for the press conference will centre around staff economic projections, reinvestment policy and TLTROs. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

* PREVIEW: Norges Bank Monetary Policy Decision Due at 09:00 GMT, 10:00 CET, 04:00EST, On Thursday 13thDecember 2018, Press Conference Due At 09:30GMT, 10:30 CET, 04:30 EST. Expectations unanimously set on an unchanged rate on 0.75%. SEB expect the Norges Bank to lift the short-term inflation trajectory. Danske Bank expect a flatter rate path for 2020-21. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

* PREVIEW: SNB Interest Rate Decision Due At 08:30GMT,03:30 EST On Thursday 13th December 2018, Press Conference At 09:00GMT, 04:00 EST. SNB widely expected to keep the 3-month Libor at -0.75% with the corridor to be held at -1.25% to -0.25%. Board members are expected to reiterate the “highly valued” CHF and preparedness for FX intervention. Focus will be on the SNB’s updated inflation forecasts given the softer November CPI and firmer CHF. Click here to access the full RANsquawk preview.

PREVIEW: US to sell USD 24bln of 10-year notes
content:
The US Treasury will auction USD 38bln of 3-year notes (Tues), USD 24bln of 10-year notes (Wed) and USD 16bln of 30-year bonds (Thu). With 10-year yields beneath the November auction stop-out rate (and all the stop-out rates going to July), analysts at SocGen say Wednesday’s auction will likely be “under pressure”. “On relative value metrics, the current note is trading rich on the Treasury spline versus old 10s compared with the previous two cycles, while it has slightly cheapened over the past two sessions on the curve versus 5s and 30s, though it is still rich compared with the previous auction levels,” the bank writes. It also suggests that the recent flattening of the 2s10s curve could be a negative, as well as the recent increase in dealer holdings. It is also worth noting that ahead of the auction, the November CPI data will be released, which could influence the tone of the auction. On the flip side, SocGen notes that current 10s are trading special in repo, which indicates a short base, which could offset headwinds.

Daily FX Wrap: Sterling resurgence continues ahead of Tory leadership ballot
content:
GBP

It remains to be seen if the latest marked recovery from deeper ytd lows in Cable and 0.9050+ vs the Eur is premature, but the Pound has made another round trip and extended its outperformance vs G10 counterparts on prospects that UK PM May will fend off the looming challenge to her leadership, and perhaps emerge from the vote of no confidence in a more secure position. Indeed, Cable is now around 1.2645 from circa 1.2478 and the cross is back near 0.9025 even though the single currency has performed pretty well in its own right against the Dollar.

EUR

As noted, Eur/Usd has bounced firmly from worst levels near 1.1300 and key support just above the big figure, with a hefty 2.4 bn option expiry also propping prices up along with reports about more convergence between Italy and the EU on 2019 budget lines, and a generally soft Greenback. The headline pair is back over 1.1350 as a result, while the DXY has pulled back further from best levels (97.500) towards 97.000 in wake of broadly as expected US CPI data and soft real earnings.

CAD/AUD/NZD

More divergence for the non-US Dollars as the Loonie derived momentum from firm oil prices and  the latest rise in overall risk sentiment to extend recovery gains beyond 1.3350, while the Aud appears to be establishing a solid base above 0.7200 as the primary currency proxy for changing US-China trade dynamics (aside from the Yuan of course – Usd/Cnh down from recent 6.9000+ highs and below the overnight Usd/Cny PBoC midpoint fix). Conversely, the Kiwi was unable to keep its head above 0.6850 as the Aud/Nzd cross reclaimed 1.0550, albeit just, and despite praise from RBNZ’s Orr for its outstanding behaviour.

JPY/CHF

The renowned, if not always conforming safe-havens remained relatively rangebound given the ongoing revival in risk appetite on latest reports that China is looking to revise intentions set out in the 2025 plan and relax rules of access for foreign companies, plus growing support for the UK Conservative Party head and speculation that Rome may be getting close to the 2% deficit mark. Usd/Jpy was capped by heavy domestic supply at 113.50 and drifted back towards 113.25, while the Franc hovered just below 0.9900.

EM

The Rand stood out amidst widespread gains vs the Buck, with more headway made on a chart basis and following SA inflation data that beat consensus – Usd/Zar testing 14.1000 from 14.3500+ at one stage.

content: Risk-on trade has received another boost from breaking Chinese trade-related headlines and reports that its 2025 mission to dominate manufacturing may be watered down, per the WSJ. Hence, core debt has extended losses with Bunds and Gilts both slipping to fresh session lows at 162.97 and 123.56, -51 and -53 ticks respectively, while BTPs consolidate gains above 125.00 (over 1 full point ahead) on hopes that Italy and the EU are getting closer to 2019 deficit alignment. Meanwhile, the DXY has reversed further from 97.500 highs to almost 97.000, but not just on latest US-China news, as the Gbp rebounds further amidst growing support for UK PM May and the Eur is encouraged by the aforementioned talk from Rome about budget compromise.

DJIA

Also, the co. said to launch texture app to come as soon as spring which could hurt revenue. Lynx research notes they are hearing of staff reduction at the co. in particular at non-core groups. Macquarie cut its price target on the stock to USD 188. (Newswires)

S&P500

NASDAQ

  • Alphabet (GOOGL) – CEO Sundar Pichai faced scrutiny yesterday from Republican lawmakers where they pressured him on the co.s political leanings, Pichai denied any political leanings on its platform. Elsewhere, more activists joined together – including NSA whistle-blower Edward Snowden - to condemn the co.’s censored China search engine “Dragonfly”. (WSJ/BI)

content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • UK PM May leadership challenge submitted by 1922 committee, with results due at 21:00GMT/16:00EST
  • US-China trade tensions marginally subside as Trump says telephone negotiations are underway
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI & Real Weekly Earnings, Brazilian Interest Rate Decision, US 10yr Auction

ASIA

Asian stocks traded higher across the board with sentiment underpinned as news flow spurred optimism regarding US-China trade relations, including reports that China submitted a proposal for review that would cut tariffs on imports of US autos to 15% from 40%. ASX 200 (+1.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.2%) gained from the open with energy and tech the front-runners in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it benefitted from USD/JPY’s slipstream and with the BoJ said to have purchased a record JPY 6tln of ETFs so far this year. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.3%) were positive on hopes of a potential tariff cut on US autos and encouraging comments from US President Trump, while news that Huawei’s CFO was released on bail and the recent better than expected lending data from China also added to the optimism. Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued with demand dampened by the gains in stocks and amid spill-over weakness from T-notes.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9064 (Prev. 6.8996)

US President Trump said China is purchasing a tremendous number of soybeans and that trade negotiations are already taking place via telephone. Furthermore, Trump said he would intervene in Huawei CFO case if it would serve national interests and trade talks with China, while he added release of Huawei CFO could be part of a broader trade deal with China. (Newswires)

Canadian judge granted bail to Huawei CFO subject to CAD 10mln guarantee including CAD 7.0mln in cash. The judge also said the CFO must surrender passports and must be subject to electronic monitoring, while the CFO is ordered to reappear in court on February 6th. (Newswires)

US President Trump administration is to condemn China over hacking and economic espionage, while there were separate reports the US State Department is mulling travel advisory for China to caution US citizens following the Huawei CFO arrest. (Washington Post/Newswires)

US House Representatives have introduced a bill that would ban the sale of US goods to Chinese telecom firms who are in violation of US export and sanctions laws, while there were separate reports that US President Trump administration is said to be mulling executive order to make it more difficult for Chinese companies to obtain critical telecom hardware. (Newswires/NYT)


UK/EU/US

Leadership challenge in May has been triggered; the 48 letters have been submitted; ballot will be held between 18.00GMT and 20.00GMT today. Results are to be announced at 21.00GMT. UK PM May said a new leader would have to extend or rescind Article 50, while adding she believes a deal with EU is attainable and within UK’s grasp after meeting with EU leaders yesterday. (Newswires)

Chairman of 1922 committee Brady says that if a leadership contest were to occur, they would want to finish the parliamentary stage before Christmas. (Newswires)

ITV's Peston tweeted that MP George Freeman appears to be saying that PM May is over, but that Tories have to find a way to replace her temporarily without a leadership election. Elsewhere, UK Shadow Brexit Minister Starmer said the opposition Labour party will call a no-confidence vote “before Christmas”. (Twitter)

European Council President Tusk noted he held a "long and frank discussion" with UK PM May ahead of EU summit and that it is clear EU27 wants to help but the question is how, while Austrian Chancellor Kurz told PM May on the phone that the Brexit deal can't be renegotiated. (Twitter/Newswires)

UK officials are reportedly warning EU members that a "no deal" Brexit raises the risk of financial disruption to banks. (Sky News)

US Treasury and USTR reportedly finalized a bilateral agreement with UK. (Newswires)

Italian PM Conte will present European Commission President Juncker a revised budget number; according to a sources at Conte's office. (Newswires)

Italian ruling coalition is not willing to reduce the 2019 deficit/GDP target to below 2.1%; according to La Repubblica. (La Repubblica)

Italian PM Conte and European Commission President Juncker's meeting is going ahead as it stands, according to Italian sources. (Newswires)

Italy's Deputy PM Salvini has denied reports (from La Repubblica) that he may pursue elections in March 2019. (Newswires)

Italian government has agreed on a new fiscal target proposal; according to an Official. (Newswires)

French Parliament to debate no confidence motion tomorrow; according to AFP. (AFP)

US President Trump said it would be foolish for the Fed to hike rates next week and that he is fighting some trade battles which needs accommodation. US President Trump also said he is not concerned about getting impeached as it is hard to impeach someone who hasn't done anything wrong, while he added that payments to women were not campaign contributions and that he relied on his former lawyer Cohen who was supposed to know what to do. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board (Euro Stoxx 50 +1.3%) following the strong performance experienced in Asia overnight after sentiment was underpinned as news flow spurred optimism regarding a US-China trade deal. France’s CAC 40 (+1.6%) outperforms its peers on the back of shares in Kering (+2.0%) amid an upgrade at Deutsche Bank and Pernod Ricard (+3.6%) after upbeat comments from activist investor Elliott on the Co. Meanwhile, Spain’s IBEX 35 (+0.80%) marginally lags peers as the index is weighed on by shares in heavyweight Inditex (-4.0%) following disappointing earnings. Moving on, sectors are experiencing broad-based gains with marginal outperformance in utility names. In terms of notable movers, auto names are performing particularly well (Stoxx 600 Auto & Parts +1.5%) in a continuation of the positive momentum from potential Chinese tariffs cuts on US autos from 40% to 15%. Meanwhile, Dixons Carphone (-8.2%) shares fell in excess of 10% at one point after the company downgraded interim dividend guidance alongside expectations for higher net debt.

FX

GBP

Not just the most volatile major, but displaying considerable resilience (or complacency?) in the face of perhaps the biggest Brexit hurdle in the form of a challenge to UK PM May’s leadership, not to mention all the political uncertainty if she fails to survive. However, Cable has recovered well from new ytd lows circa 1.2478 and almost reached 1.2550 before waning again as a number of high profile Cabinet members voiced public support for the current Conservative head in the run up to tonight’s confidence vote. A hefty 1 bn option expiry at the 1.2500 strike may be exerting a gravitational pull, while Eur/Gbp is pivoting 0.9950, as the single currency continues to weather its own storm via Italian and French budget excesses.

NZD/SEK

In contrast to Sterling’s stellar performance, the Kiwi and Swedish Krona have slipped to the bottom of the G10 ranks, as Nzd/Usd reverses from 0.6900 to within a few pips of 0.6850, regardless of RBNZ Orr’s assertion that the currency has been ‘remarkably’ obedient, and Eur/Sek rebounds sharply from sub-10.3000 to just over 10.3700 at one stage in wake of softer than forecast Swedish inflation data. Note, the Riksbank’s preferred CPIF measure was especially benign and well below the Bank’s own estimate, undermining December hike expectations to around evens.

EUR/AUD/CAD/CHF/JPY

All narrowly mixed vs a generally firmer Greenback (DXY just off a fresh 97.500 recent peak) and the ongoing revival in broad risk sentiment amidst heightened hopes of a tangible improvement in US-China trade relations. Eur/Usd has survived another, deeper test of 1.1300 support where a massive 2.4 bn expiries reside and are perhaps helping to keep the headline pair cushioned against Italian/French deficit issues ahead of Thursday’s ECB policy meeting. Meanwhile, the Aud and Loonie are feeding off the aforementioned improved risk appetite, with the former holding above 0.7200 and latter rebounding a bit further from 1.3400+ lows with the added incentive of rebounding crude prices. The Franc is meandering in a tight range between 0.9950-20 and encircling 1.1250 vs the Eur awaiting the final 2018 SNB Quarterly review tomorrow, while Usd/Jpy is equally restrained within 113.50-30 trading parameters with the topside said to be laden with Japanese offers.

EM

In contrast to the Sek, firmer than expected SA CPI has underpinned the Zar around 14.3100 vs the Dollar, but the Rand may also be drawing momentum from option-related flows alongside bullish technical impulses as 1 bn expiries roll off at the 14.5000 strike today

FIXED INCOME

Gilts are still off worst levels but have printed a new low to trade around the 124.00 handle as more MP’s come out in support of the PM, including key ministers such as Gove, Mourdant and Williamson and the running total of those in support >70 ahead of the no confidence vote results at 9pm.  Meanwhile, Bunds have seen similar price action with the German 10-year settling just below 163.40 after failing to test Monday’s 162.59 high, with German participants keeping a close eye on no-confidence developments and Italian and French counterparts. On that note, BTPs extend their outperformance vs. their EU counterparts (fresh high at 124.37) amidst suggestions the EU will take a softer approach given France’s budget position alongside now refuted suggestions of an early election and PM Conte set to present revised budget numbers to Juncker.  OATs are recovering some composure and almost touched 151.00 after yesterday’s heavy losses and underperformance with the French 10-year trading with gains of over 10 ticks.

Elsewhere, US Treasuries see little action ahead of issuance later in the day in the form of a 10 year auction with US 2s/10s building a solid base above 10bps, with the US also releasing CPI figures.

COMMODITIES 

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (7 Dec) -10.18mln vs. Exp. -3.0mln (Prev. +5.36mln). (Newswires)

WTI (+1.8%) and Brent (+1.7%) trade with firm gains amid the improvement in the risk sentiment as US-Sino trade discussion seem to be on track, with US President Trump expressing optimism via Twitter yesterday. Furthermore, prices may be underpinned in light of last night’s API crude inventories which showed a much wider-than-expected draw of 10.18mln barrels vs. the expected draw of 3.0mln barrels. Traders will be eyeing this afternoon’s weekly DoE inventory release for a fresh catalyst (alongside production numbers) in which crude inventories are expected to decrease by 3.0mln barrels.

In terms of metals, spot gold (+0.1%) remains steady as the dollar index remains within a tight range while copper traded sideways near weekly highs in light of the improvement in risk sentiment. Elsewhere, Shanghai steel snapped a three-day losing streak amid talks of production cuts at the top steelmaking city, Tangshan.

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures underpinned as UK PM May undermined
content: It’s almost a classic case of ‘buy rumour/sell fact’, or in this instance vice-versa for UK debt and STIR contracts that kicked off Liffe on the front foot, but perhaps not as much above parity as might be expected given the impending vote of confidence in PM May. Indeed, the 10 year debt future has drifted back below yesterday’s settlement price and below 124.00 to 123.93 having rallied to 124.28 at best (+19 ticks), while the 3 month strip has whittled gains of up to 6 ticks and just dipped into the red before stabilising again, as initial perceptions and knee-jerk buying on political instability gradually wane amidst high profile Cabinet members coming out in support of the incumbent Conservative Party leader.

content: The 10 year German benchmark briefly recouped all and a bit more of its losses on breaking headlines confirming that UK PM May will face a leadership challenge later today after Tory party rebels gained enough letters to trigger a ballot. Bunds just faded off a fresh 153.53 Eurex high vs Tuesday’s 163.48 close having been 28 ticks below par at one stage amidst a further recovery in US and Asia-Pacific equities alongside a rally in BTPs on the perhaps misguided basis that the EU may be more tolerant about a 2%+ 2019 deficit given the probability if not inevitability of France exceeding the 3% limit next year. Ahead, Eurozone ip data the sole macro release before attention turns, at some stage, to tomorrow’s ECB policy meeting with fresh staff forecasts and latest guidance.

Rolls-Royce (RR/ LN) – Co. confirmed FY guidance and expects both core profit and cash flow for 2018 to be in the upper half of FY guidance. (Newswires)

British American Tobacco (BATS LN) – Co. says FY adj. EPS growth is expected to be impacted by currency headwinds, and continue to expect US industry cigarette volume to be down 4.0%-4.5% in 2018. THP and vapour remain in track to reach forecasts and FY guidance remains unchanged. Furthermore, board member Lionel Nowell announced his retirement. (Newswires)

Dixons Carphones (DC/ LN) – Co. says H1 results were as expected. Co. reaffirmed profit before tax guidance, increased net debt guidance (GBP 274mln vs. Prev. GBP 206mln), and downgraded interim dividend guidance (GBP 0.0225 vs. Prev. GBP 0.0350). (Newswires)

Sainsburys (SBRY LN) – Co. and Asda has appealed for mote time for merger probe by the UK CMA. Co,s asked the CMA for an additional 11 working days over the Christmas period to respond to a large amount of material recently provided. (Newswires)

John Wood Group (WG/ LN) – Co. says performance is in line with guidance, FY results will demonstrate good organic growth and Co. anticipates further earnings growth in 2019. (Newswires)

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

12th December 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700GMT/0100CST recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700GMT/0100CST all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715GMT/0115CST.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750GMT/0150CST recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715GMT/0115CST ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded higher across the board with sentiment underpinned as news flow spurred optimism regarding US-China trade relations, including reports that China submitted a proposal for review that would cut tariffs on imports of US autos to 15% from 40%. ASX 200 (+1.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.3%) gained from the open with energy and tech the front-runners in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it benefitted from USD/JPY’s slipstream and with the BoJ said to have purchased a record JPY 6tln of ETFs so far this year. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were positive on hopes of a potential tariff cut on US autos and encouraging comments from US President Trump, while news that Huawei’s CFO was released on bail and the recent better than expected lending data from China also added to the optimism.

FTSE

Shell (RDSA LN) – Russian head of Co. says talks about a possible asset swap deal with Gazprom has been suspended; according to Russian press. (Kommersant)

Vodafone (VOD LN) – European competition regulator is looking into Vodafone’s EUR 18.4bln takeover of Liberty Global’s European cable business. The regulator warned that the deal could reduce competition in two out of four territories where Vodafone is buying assets, Germany and the Czech Republic. (Times)

Anglo American (AAL LN) – Co.’s platinum division has completed the disposal of 33% interest in the BRPM (Bafoken Rasimone Platinum Mine) joint venture. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

MAN GROUP (EMG LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

METRO BANK (MTRO LN) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM BUY AT CITI

DAX

Volkswagen (VOW3 GY), Daimler (DAI GY) – The two automakers car sharing units’ merger will happen at the earliest in 2019. (Newswires)

Linde (LIN GY) – Co. is to hold an extraordinary shareholder meeting to finalise its merger with Praxair (PX). (Newswires)

Siemens (SIE GY)/ Alstom (ALO FP) – Co.’s are to submit a remedy package to the European Commissions with include mainly signalling activities as well as rolling stock products. Alstom says there is no certainty that the content of this package will be sufficient to elevate concerns of the Commission in regards to their merger.

ThyssenKrupp (TKA GY) – Co.’s supervisory board is considering whether to appoint Martina Merz as their new Chief, according to reports. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 12th December 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian stocks traded higher across the board with sentiment underpinned as news flow spurred optimism regarding US-China trade relations
  • Multiple sources in the UK believe that the 48 letter threshold has been reached to trigger a confidence vote in UK PM May; yet to be confirmed
  • Most major FX pairs attempted to nurse losses against the greenback with EUR and GBP regaining some ground vs. the USD
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US CPI & Real Weekly Earnings, Brazilian Interest Rate Decision, OPEC Monthly Report, UK I/L 2048 Gilt Auction, US 10yr Auction

ASIA

Asian stocks traded higher across the board with sentiment underpinned as news flow spurred optimism regarding US-China trade relations, including reports that China submitted a proposal for review that would cut tariffs on imports of US autos to 15% from 40%. ASX 200 (+1.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+2.3%) gained from the open with energy and tech the front-runners in Australia, while the Japanese benchmark outperformed as it benefitted from USD/JPY’s slipstream and with the BoJ said to have purchased a record JPY 6tln of ETFs so far this year. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+1.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.2%) were positive on hopes of a potential tariff cut on US autos and encouraging comments from US President Trump, while news that Huawei’s CFO was released on bail and the recent better than expected lending data from China also added to the optimism. Finally, 10yr JGBs are subdued with demand dampened by the gains in stocks and amid spill-over weakness from T-notes.

PBoC skipped open market operations. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.9064 (Prev. 6.8996)

US President Trump said China is purchasing a tremendous amount of soybeans and that trade negotiations are already taking place via telephone. Furthermore, Trump said he would intervene in Huawei CFO case if it would serve national interests and trade talks with China, while he added release of Huawei CFO could be part of a broader trade deal with China. (Newswires)

Canadian judge granted bail to Huawei CFO subject to CAD 10mln guarantee including CAD 7.0mln in cash. The judge also said the CFO must surrender passports and must be subject to electronic monitoring, while the CFO is ordered to reappear in court on February 6th. (Newswires)

US President Trump administration is to condemn China over hacking and economic espionage, while there were separate reports the US State Department is mulling travel advisory for China to caution US citizens following the Huawei CFO arrest. (Washington Post/Newswires)

US House Representatives have introduced a bill that would ban the sale of US goods to Chinese telecom firms who are in violation of US export and sanctions laws, while there were separate reports that US President Trump administration is said to be mulling executive order to make it more difficult for Chinese companies to obtain critical telecom hardware. (Newswires/NYT)


UK/EU

A UK senior government source was said to be expecting a confidence vote in UK PM May imminently and there were also reports that the 1922 Committee is set to meet on Wednesday evening. Furthermore, there were initial reports that 1922 Committee Chairman Brady has asked to see the PM May after PMQs tomorrow and that multiple sources believe the threshold of 48 letters has been reached, although there were separate reports that friends of Brady said he has no plans to make a statement about a confidence vote on UK PM May's leadership and that Brady is said to not have sought a crisis meeting with UK PM May. (Newswires/Twitter) UK PM May has not been told that leadership threshold was met according to a source, although a Telegraph political correspondent later tweeted that a senior Brexiteer said 48 letters have "almost definitely" gone in and expect an announcement today. (Newswires/Twitter)

ITV's Peston tweeted that MP George Freeman appears to be saying that PM May is over but that Tories have to find a way to replace her temporarily without a leadership election. Elsewhere, UK Shadow Brexit Minister Starmer said the opposition Labour party will call a no-confidence vote “before Christmas”. (Twitter)

European Council President Tusk noted he held a "long and frank discussion" with UK PM May ahead of EU summit and that it is clear EU27 wants to help but the question is how, while Austrian Chancellor Kurz told PM May on the phone that the Brexit deal can't be renegotiated. (Twitter/Newswires)

UK officials are reportedly warning EU members that a "no deal" Brexit raises the risk of financial disruption to banks. (Sky News)

US Treasury and USTR reportedly finalized a bilateral agreement with UK. (Newswires)

Italy's Deputy PM Salvini may pursue elections in March 2019, according to La Repubblica. (La Repubblica)


FX

In FX markets, most major pairs attempted to nurse losses against the greenback in which EUR/USD recuperated after the prior day’s drop from resistance at 1.1400 and with GBP/USD just about clawing back the 1.2500 handle after the recent pounding it took from PM May’s Brexit vote retreat. Elsewhere, the increased risk appetite dampened demand for safe-haven JPY and antipodeans strengthened amid gains in crude as well as outperformance in CNH, while high-beta CAD also benefitted from the risk sentiment and following the Huawei CFO bail release.
 

COMMODITIES

Commodities traded with mild gains with WTI crude futures higher by 1% and back above the 52.00/bbl level following a much larger than expected drawdown in the latest headline API crude inventory report, while the EIA also conducted upward revisions to global oil demand forecasts for this year and next. Elsewhere, gold heads into the European session relatively flat albeit off worse levels after having recovered from some of the prior day’s USD-induced losses, and copper traded sideways near this week’s highs with price kept afloat by the improved risk sentiment.

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (7 Dec) -10.18mln vs. Exp. -3.0mln (Prev. +5.36mln). (Newswires)

US EIA raised its 2018 world oil demand growth forecast by 20,000 BPD to 1.54mln BPD YY and raised 2019 forecast by 80,000 BPD to 1.52mln BPD YY. EIA also forecasts 2019 US crude oil output to rise by 1.18mln BPD (prev. 1.16mln) to 12.06mln BPD and forecasts 2019 US oil demand to rise by 330,000 BPD (prev. 220,000). (Newswires)

Iraqi PM Abdul Mahdi said will send delegation to the US to discuss exemption from sanctions on Iran in order to keep importing Iranian gas. (Newswires)

US


Treasuries traded lower in Asia amid low volume and continued to sell into the European open. As US traders sat at their desks, the complex edged gradually higher and extended gains on reports suggesting Trump administration is condemning China over hacking and economic espionage Trump administration to condemn China over hacking and economic espionage as well as Trump threatening a government shutdown. Nonetheless the complex finished Tuesday’s session in negative territory as equities pared back some of their losses and turned positive heading into the close.  Most of the action was concentrated in the front end of the curve where yields were higher by c.5bps at settlement. US T-note futures (Z8) settled 7+ ticks lower at 120-14+.

US President Trump said it would be foolish for the Fed to hike rates next week and that he is fighting some trade battles which needs accommodation. US President Trump also said he is not concerned about getting impeached as it is hard to impeach someone who hasn't done anything wrong, while he added that payments to women were not campaign contributions and that he relied on his former lawyer Cohen who was supposed to know what to do. (Newswires)
